body_content.explanation: to burn brightly either for a short time or not regularly:
examples: The flame above the oil well flared up into the dark sky.
New fires flared and people were told to leave their homes.

body_content.explanation: When something bad such as violence, pain, or anger flares (up), it suddenly starts or gets much worse:
examples: Violence flared up again last night.
Tempers flared after a three-hour delay at the Airport yesterday.
He flared his nostrils in rage.
The skirt fits tightly over the hips and flares just below the knees.

body_content.explanation: a sudden increase in the brightness of a fire:
examples: There was a sudden flare when she threw the petrol onto the fire.

body_content.explanation: a very bright light or coloured smoke that can be used as a signal, or a device that produces this:
examples: We set off a flare to help guide our rescuers.
Every agent is given a pack with rations, signal flares, and a first-aid kit.

body_content.explanation: trousers that get wider below the knee:
examples: He grew his hair long and started to wear flares.

body_content.explanation: the fact of something, especially clothing, becoming wider at one end:
examples: This skirt has a definite flare.

body_content.explanation: in American football, a short throw to a back who is running towards the sideline:
examples: Under pressure, he threw a flare to Wilson that lost three yards.
He caught a flare pass from Merino and managed to make seven yards.

body_content.explanation: in baseball, a ball that is hit a short distance through the air into the outfield:
examples: Pitch him away and he gets his little flares and infield hits.
Jones hit a flare to right that fell just inside the line.

body_content.explanation: in gymnastics, a movement in which the gymnast balances on their hands and moves their legs wide apart in a circular movement:
examples: It was an immaculate performance, full of crowd-pleasing flares and eye-catching manoeuvres.
The American lost his rhythm on a flare sequence and finished sixth.
